subject: Re: [junit] What's wrong with using inner classes for tests?
msgSnippet: 1. Cannot deliver without tests, so your delivery is bloated 2. Personally speaking, it clutters the class definition, making it more time consuming to
messageBody:
1. Cannot deliver without tests, so your delivery is bloated
2. Personally speaking, it clutters the class definition, making it more
time consuming to navigate the file (yes, IDEs can help with this,
but...)
3. Automated suite generation is more difficult
4. Inner classes are member variables of the object; they usually do
something for the object's functionality that the object doesn't want to
do itself --> Are your tests really extensions/helpers to your object's
functionality?
5. Why not just put it in its own file? It's just as easy and not at
all hard to keep in sync.

=jason

On Wed, 2003-04-09 at 10:33, Sandy McArthur wrote: Searching the message
archive there seems to be three common places to
put your tests.

1) Next to the class you are testing but in the same directory.
2) Next to the class you are testing but in a different directory.
3) In a public static inner class.

From my current point of view the third option looks the most
appealing to me but most people seem to recomend the second.

Can anyone give some good reasons to advoid the third choice? I'm all
too familar with seemingly clever ideas that fail badly when a project
gets large and would prefer to learn from other people's mistakes.

Thanks in advance.
